The dashed lines represent isotherms. (a) Let <math alttext="W"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the work done on the gas, <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the energy transferred to the gas by heating, and <math alttext="delta U"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the change in the internal energy of the gas during the process shown. i. Is <math alttext="W"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to zero? Briefly explain your answer.
ii. Is <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to zero? Briefly explain your answer.
iii. Is <math alttext="delta U"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to zero? Briefly explain your answer.

(b) If the temperature of the gas in state <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="200 kelvin"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the approximate temperature of the gas in state <math alttext="B"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?
(c) Is your numerical result for part (b) consistent with your explanation for part (a)(iii)? Briefly justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
